Label: EJSM
Scope note: The painting having been previously lined see EJL. The mounting silks were lined using a mulberry paper of suitable weight of the Mino type. The paper is adhered using a fresh wheat starch paste, and left to dry on felt. The various silks were then balanced for flexibility by adding more layers of Misu paper, and adhered using a dilute aged paste, the paper/s was secured using a pounding brush (UCHIBAKE). When each part of the mount including the painting were matched in flexibility they were lightly moistened using water and flattened on the drying board. After one week the silks and painting were removed. The silks were trimmed and the mount was assembled using wheat starch paste. The cut edges of silk being first sealed with paste. Joints were hammered to secure. The edges of the scroll were cut and turned in, the seam being adhered using thick aged paste and hammered to secure. A water torn strip of paper was then added to the edge prior to the mount being lined using Misu paper and dilute aged paste. The scroll was left to dry overnight before being moistened with water and flattened on a drying board. The scroll was left for two weeks. The last backing was applied using Uda paper and adhered using Uchibake / aged paste. The silk cover was also attached using aged paste. Two silk strenghening strips were applied using aged paste to the roller line on the bottom pocket. The scroll was allowed to dry overnight before being moistened with water and flattened on a drying board. The scroll was left for two weeks, face out. Joints were checked before the scroll was removed from the drying board, burnished on the verso using glass beads and Ibota wax. The scroll was the re-attached to the drying board using a little moisture and wheat starch paste. The scroll was left for six months. On removal the paper edges were trimmed off and the roller and stave attached using strong wheat starch paste. Kan were nailed onto the top stave and the hanging braid knotted on.

Label: EJSR
Scope note: A suitable weight of repair silk was chosen matching the thread counts of warp and weft as closely as possible. This was lined using a weak wheat starch paste adhesive. The lined silk was then toned to a level of colour lighter than the original. Each repair was copied onto tracing paper and cut out of the lined repair silk. The repair was adhered using a mixture of new starch paste and funori (seaweed adhesive) 50:50. Once in place the support paper was moistened using water and removed from the face of the silk repair. The whole repair is then lightly moistened to allow the repair to pull down into place. On drying the silk repair is brushed with soy milk 5% prior to toning with artists water colour to a neutral colour.

The Plastazote layers were attached to an Aerolam F board (glass fibre, epoxy laminate on aluminium honeycomb) base of appropriate dimensions, which had been covered with a taut layer of cotton lawn, adhered usingVinamul 3252 (polyvinyl acetate, ethylene copolymer). Layers of polyester wadding were placed inside the recess, to match the contours of the reverse side of the portrait. The mount was then covered with dyed cotton jersey, attached by stitching into the cotton lawn around the inside edges of the recess and heatsealed using Vinamul 3252 to the lip at the bottom edge, before securing by stitching on the reverse side of the mount. A colour-matched card frame was cut with an aperture the same size as the portrait. The edges of the aperture were bevelled, with the bevelled edge facing inwards so that the white core of the card was not visible. The card frame was strengthened by an additional piece of card adhered to the reverse. Shaped Plastazote pieces, tinted using acrylic paints, were attached to the reverse of the card to hold in place the top and bottom edges of the portrait. Dyed cotton tape was adhered to the reverse side of the card frame to extend around the sides of the mount and attach by means of Velcro tabs to the reverse of the mount. Scope note: The surface of the object was protected with several layers of clingfilm and then the head turned over onto it's face. All the internal surfaces were then lined with aluminium foil, taking care to eliminate any undercuts. The edges were bent over the rim of the mask. Cut sections of parcel tape were applied to all areas of the aluminium foil making sure that there were no pin-holes left uncovered. Aluminium tape was used to re-inforce the edges of the mask. A wall of foil was then built along the rim of the mask to prevent any overflow of resin from seeping onto the painted surfaces. This was also re-inforced with aluminium tape and parcel tape. All of these surfaces were coated in lascaux wax (microcrystalline wax, synthetic polyterpene) A mixture of foaming epoxy resin: Araldite CW 2215 resin, Hardner HY 5161 and foaming agent DY 5054 was made up in the following proportions: R.100gx H 20gx F 2g. This was poured into the prepared mask. NB. The foaming agent was doubled in order to make the mount lighter. Once set, the mount was removed from the mask and 'shaped' using abrasive papers and a combination of files. Holes etc. were filled with 20% Paraloid B72 (ethyl methacrylate co polymer) in acetone /industrial methylated spirits and microballoons ( silica or phenilic resin). Scoops were cut out from the back of the mount to facilitate handling. The mount was then painted to an acceptable colour for the mask.

Scope note: The painting having been previously lined see EL. The mountinf silks were lined using a mulberry paper of a suitable weight of the Mino type. The paper is adhered using a fresh wheat starch paste, and left to dry on felt. The various silks were then balanced for flexibility by adding more layers of Misu paper, and adhered using a dilute aged paste, the paper/s was secured using a pouding brush (UCHIBAKE). When each part of the mount including the painting were matched in flexibility they were lightly moistened using water, and flattened on the drying board. After one week the silks and painting were removed. The silks were trimmed and the mount was assembled using wheat starch paste. The cut edges of silk being first sealed with paste. Joints were hammered to secure. A water torn strip was then added to the edge prior to the mount being lined using Misu paper and dilute aged paste. The scroll was left todry overnight before moistened with water and flattened on a drying board. The scroll was left for two weeks. The last backing was applied using Uda paper and adhered using Uchibake / aged paste. The silk cover was attached using aged paste. Two silk strengthing strips were applied using aged paste to the roller line on the bottom pocket. The scroll was allowed to dry overnight before being moistened with water and flattened on a drying board. The scroll was left for two weeks, face out. Joints were checked before the scroll was removed from the drying board, burnished on the verso using glass beads and Ibota wax. The scroll was then re-attached to the drying board using a little moisture and wheat starch paste. The scroll was left for six months. On removal the paper edges were trimmed off, and the roller and stave attached using strong wheat starch paste. Kan were nailed onto the top stave and the hanging braid knotted on.
